com.orientechnologies.orient.core.storage.cache

Interface OReadCache

  • All Known Implementing Classes:
    O2QCache, ODirectMemoryOnlyDiskCache

    public interface OReadCache
    This class is heart of OrientDB storage model it presents disk backed data cache which works with direct memory.

    Model of this cache is based on page model. All direct memory area is mapped to disk files and each file is split on pages. Page is smallest unit of work. The amount of RAM which can be used for data manipulation is limited so only a subset of data will be really loaded into RAM on demand, if there is not enough RAM to store all data, part of them will by flushed to the disk. If disk cache is closed all changes will be flushed to the disk.

    Typical steps if you work with disk cache are following:

    1. Open file using #openFile(String, OWriteCache) method
    2. Remember id of opened file
    3. Load page which you want to use to write data using method #load(long, long, boolean, OWriteCache, int)
    4. Get pointer to the memory page OCacheEntry.getCachePointer()
    5. Lock allocated page for writes OCachePointer.acquireExclusiveLock()
    6. Get pointer to the direct memory which is allocated to hold page data OCachePointer#getDataPointer()
    7. Change page content as you wish.
    8. Release page write lock OCachePointer.releaseExclusiveLock()
    9. Mark page as dirty so it will be flushed eventually to the disk OCacheEntry.markDirty()
    10. Put page back to the cache release(OCacheEntry, OWriteCache)

    If you wish to read data, not change them, you use the same steps but:

    1. Acquire read lock instead of write lock using OCachePointer.acquireSharedLock()
      2. method.
    2. Do not mark page as dirty

    If you want to add new data but not to change existing one and you do not have enough space to add new data use method #allocateNewPage(long, OWriteCache) instead of #load(long, long, boolean, OWriteCache, int).

    #load(long, long, boolean, OWriteCache, int) method has checkPinnedPages parameter. Pinned pages are pages which are kept always loaded in RAM ,this class of pages is needed for some data structures usually this attribute should be set to false and it is set to true when storage goes through data restore procedure after system crash.

    Since:
    14.03.13
    Author:
    Andrey Lomakin
